newsitem.title: UK: Oil price stays buoyant on high demand, low stocks.
newsitem.headline: Oil price stays buoyant on high demand, low stocks.

text.p: World oil prices remained buoyant near four-month highs on Friday, consolidating the week's gains amid strong demand and tight inventories.

October London futures for international benchmark Brent Blend crude at 1621 GMT were trading one cent down from Thursday at $20.74 after earlier touching $21 a barrel. Brent is running some $4 in advance of this time last year but analysts said they saw no sign of any immediate significant retreat.
They cited low stocks of heating oil and diesel (distillates), rising demand from major industrialised nations and a subdued supply outlook for the remainder of the year.

"Distillate fundamentals look tight in the next couple of months given the strong demand outlook diesel (harvest demand) and heating oil and the current situation of dangerously low stocks worldwide," said Washington-based Petroleum Finance Company.
"The demand picture in the third quarter looks much stronger than previously expected, especially in the OECD countries," Petroleum Finance said.
Helping prices on Friday was renewed speculation that the resumption of Iraqi crude exports under an oil-for-food deal with the United Nations might get further delayed.

A senior U.N. relief official in Baghdad said on Friday he was discussing with the Iraqis how to overcome a number of vital operational issues concerning humanitarian goods distribution in northern Iraq.
"There are still serious operational problems to look at," U.N. food programme director Holdbrook Arthur said.

Analysts said any delays to Iraq's first exports for six years, agreed with the United Nations in May, would underpin prices at a time when some new oilfield projects were taking longer to come onstream than planned.
"Global oil supplies are now set to increase steadily throughout the rest of the year rather than surge in the next two months," said Petroleum Finance.
"A more subdued supply outlook has diminished the likelihood of a glut developing when Iraqi exports commence."
Crude oil prices in dollars per barrel:
